text: Going back to when I first started and I was obsessively thinking about this stuff and thinking about risk, I've always been of the mindset that I want to get paid when I'm correct. And that's really, really important because that won't lead you into sort of what I would say shaky strategies like selling skew, like selling tail risk, because that's what you'll see a lot of people, that's the route you'll see them go is, well, okay, I'll sell this five delta option in the SPX. I can still get a nominally decent amount of premium. I'll sell that. I don't do that. And to answer your question, the reason why it goes back to all the random data and all the backtesting and all the research, what you find is, so I'm a proponent, I'm a subscriber to the Kelly criterion in terms of whether it's at the portfolio level or it's at the individual trade level. I just think that it's so useful. And if it's already been done, if this stuff has already been figured out for you, then you might as well use it. And so one of the things that I've found I built a very simple spreadsheet, but what you see is that the smaller the credit that you take, now, obviously there are some assumptions in here about probability of a trade being profitable, et cetera, et cetera, stuff that I don't necessarily like to rely on, but you need it in order to run the simulation. Well, what you find is, is the smaller the credit that you take in under a Kelly framework for managing option spreads is you essentially have to stay in that trade and you have to hold that trade through expiration. It has to be a terminal position. And whereas the closer you get to the money, you get several better properties. One, you can manage at 60%. Once you've taken in 60% of the premium, then you can take the trade off and over a thousand or 10,000 trades, you'll still have a positive expected value. With the tail stuff that people love to sell, they don't understand. Let's say you sell that option for a dollar. You have to take all of that dollar or 95 cents of it. There is no, oh, I'm looking at the price of that. I'm looking at the value of that. I'm looking at the value of that. I'm looking at the markets today and it's looking shaky, but I've gotten 60 cents of this dollar. No, you have to sit in it that whole time because in the short term, you may be relieved and that may be psychologically appealing, but there's going to be a time when you lose multiples of that. And so you have to account for that. And the cool thing about Kelly is we don't have to go through the pain of experiencing these different trials. The equation can give us the wisdom ahead of time. So we don't have to make those mistakes. And so for me, I want to be closer to the money. So you don't have to be in the middle of the market. You don't have to be in the middle of the market. You'll never see me go on a short option sort of structure. I won't go less than like a 30 or 35 Delta because I want feedback. The other thing about going that far out, taking small credits is I don't really know if I have an edge in forecasting or not. I can just be fooled by the fact that I'm so far away that I never really am close to the action. I may not have an edge in forecasting. So I want quick feedback on whether I was right or wrong, because therefore I can go back and if I'm using GARCH or if I'm using, in my cases, just to glorify exponentially, weighted moving average. But I can go back and I can iterate on this. And I say, okay, what inputs do I need to feed to try to get better forecast? So there's that. And then there's the fact that the closer you get to the money, you can potentially get, there may be times where you really nail it and you can get 0.8 on your risk or 0.9 on your risk. And that's great. And then lastly, it turns the stock a lot quicker. So yeah, there's a ton of gamma near the money, but because you're so close, it goes linear really quickly. So if there's a time where I need to scramble and I usually hedge with ES futures, right? So I'll flatten the delta and I can do it and not worry about this sort of convex profile, this extreme convexity where even your implied volatility exposure has like a gamma-like component to it. And so for those reasons, that's why I want to get a decent meaty credit and then manage from there.
